citation.article-title: Biochemical characterization of Serratia liquefaciens sensu stricto, Serratia proteamaculans and Serratia grimesii sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Serratia grimesii sp. nov.
Serratia grimesii (grimesii is a Modern Latin, genitive, masculine form of Grimes, in honor of Michael Grimes, Irish bacteriologist, who first described this group)
Strain ATCC 14460 and 10 other strains (group Cld) that correspond to the description given by Grimes [9] form a discrete biochemical and genomic group.

This group is distinct from all other Serratia species and from other genera in the Enterobacteriaceae by DNA-relatedness criteria. Serratia grimesii with strain ATCC 14460 as the type strain. S. grimesii has been isolated from the natural environment and from human clinical specimens.
Group Adc might be a subspecies of S. grimesii.
However, only three strains of this rare group were studied.
No taxonomic proposal will be made until more strains are available for study.
Carbon-source utilization tests are useful in the identification of newly described Enterobacteriaceae.
These tests might be difficult to carry out in clinical laboratories unless carbon-source utilization tests are included in commercial identification kits.
For those laboratories which cannot differentiate S. liquefaciens sensu stricto, S. proteamaculans, and S. grimesii, we suggest the use of the vernacular name "S. liquefaciens-like".
